results.title: Damn it. B.Y.O.
results.brief_description: 1. “Damn it” (Sweden, 1980, 20 min.): An animated film showing the physical and emotional stresses experienced by a young man in a big city. 2. “BYO” (Brisbane, 1980, 19 min.): A dramatisation of a school dance where smuggling alcohol causes more trouble than it’s worth.

results.title: Dame Margaret Scott
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers”.
Dame Margaret Scott talks about her experiences touring England with the “Sadler’s Wells Ballet” and “Ballet Rambert” during the Second World War and her association with choreographers John Cranko and Kenneth MacMillan. When a recurring back injury ended her dancing career, Scott moved to Australia and became a teacher. She offered to help Peggy van Praagh prepare dancers for the formation of the “Australian Ballet Company” and went on to establish the “Australian Ballet School”. Scott discusses the relationship between the school and the performing company and her desire to produce dancers with both a sound classical technique and an ability to adapt to the demands of contemporary dance.

results.title: Dame Kiri Te Kanawa: my world of opera
results.brief_description: Dame Kiri Te Kanawa introduces a personal selection of her own favourite operatic scenes recorded at some of the world’s major venues and shares with viewers her recollections of memorable performances from the world of opera. Featured are: Thomas Allen, Vladimir Atlantov, Janet Baker, Barbara Bonney, Jose Carreras, Ileana Cotrubas, Placido Domingo, Mirella Freni, Robert Lloyd and Neil Shicoff. The venues cover the plush and gilt interior of the Royal Opera House Covent Garden, the magnificent Teatro alla Scala, Milan and Arena di Verona, and the more intimate surroundings of Glyndebourne where Opera and picturesque English countryside make for a pleasant harmony. Sumptuous costumes, glimmering jewels, spectacular sets and spine tingling song all add up to an unforgettable experience. Dame Kiri relates some of the experiences she has encountered as an opera singer. Placido Domingo demonstrates his versatility when he conducts the orchestra in a performance of Die Fledermaus and also provides the occasion for some comic relief. Included are excerpts from the following operas: Der Rosenkavalier, The Tales of Hoffman, Don Carlo, La Boheme, Die Fledermaus, Ernani, Andrea Chenier, Nabucco, Otello, La Cenerentola, and Orfeo ed Euridice.

results.title: Dame Edna glasses
results.brief_description:
Dame Edna Everage has been making generations of Australians laugh (and cringe) since she burst on the scene in 1955.

Barry Humphries created the character of Edna Everage (as in average) from the Melbourne suburb of Moonee Ponds whilst touring with a group of actors around Victoria. She was a caricature of mayor’s wives they met on the road and was named after his childhood nanny.

results.title: Dame Edith Sitwell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Face to Face”.
John Freeman interviews Dame Edith Sitwell with the aim of observing the person behind the public face. A distinguished poet who lists her recreations as “listening to music and silence”. She received honorary doctorates from the Universities of Leeds, Durham, Oxford and Sheffield and was an Honorary Associate of the American Institute of Arts and Letters. Her first poems were published in 1915. This interview was recorded in 1959. Dame Edith Sitwell died on 9th December, 1964, at the age of 77, a few days after finishing her memoirs “Taken care of”. Drawings by Feliks Topolski.

results.title: Damascus
results.brief_description: Part of the Vagabond Adventure series, shows scenes of Damascus including buildings, ruins, bazaars, streetscapes, artisans at work on intricate mother-of-pearl inlays, brass ornaments and the market places. Narrated by Alois Hovrilla.

results.title: Damage (E)
results.creator_credit: Skerba NEF, Studio Canal+, Channel 4 and Louis Malle
results.brief_description: Jeremy Irons and Juliette Binoche star in this Louis Malle erotic film about dangerous sexual obsession. Irons, a respected MP, becomes attracted and then involved with his son’s fiance Anna. Despite his promising career, his successful marriage to Miranda Richardson and the love he bears for his son, he cannot bear to give Anna up, and they pursue a dangerous affair which ultimately ends in tragedy. Martin, played by Rupert Graves becomes the innocent victim of their deceit. Miranda Richardson gives a strong albeit brief performance, while Leslie Caron makes a cameo appearance as Anna’s mother.

results.title: Dama a sobachkoi = Lady with the little dog
results.brief_description:
In Yalta, at the end of the 19th century, an unhappily married woman goes on a holiday alone, walking her dog daily to relive her ennui. A banker named Dimitri, beguiled by Anna’s beauty, admires her from afar, himself suffering in a miserable arranged marriage. The two embark upon a hopeless affair, which Anna assumes will end with the holiday. Dimitri returns to Moscow but distracted by the memory of Anna, contrives to see her again. Back in Saratov, Anna is equally as depressed and most surprised when Dimitri arrives at a concert she is attending. Drawn together by their misery, the lovers continue to meet intermittently in the hope of salvaging a schism of love from their ruined lives. Displaying a fondness for the manners and social mores of turn of the century Russia, Heifits contrasts the brightness of Yalta in summer (symbolic of the passionate beginnings of the affair), with the cold Moscow winter. The low-key direction and emotional undercurrents of the film adequately reflect the power of Chekhov’s prose.

Credits: Director, writer, Josef Heifits ; photography, Andrei Moskvin, D. Meschiev ; music, Jiri Sternwald.
Cast: Iya Savvina, Aleksei Batalov, Nina Alisova, Pantelejmon Krymov, D. Zebrovv, M. Safonova.
